metadata.title: Ship of Opportunity: Canada to Japan - 1980-present
metadata.description: Data from merchant ships travelling between British Columbia and Japan, from 1980-1990 (Canada Ace), 1995 to 2000, continuing (Skaugran), and 1999-2000, continuing (Alligator Hope). Data collected include surface total carbon dioxide, alkalinity, nutrients, chlorophyll a, carbon-13 in seawater, and atmospheric carbon-13. Underway measurements include position, time, temperature and salinity. Skaugran samples and data were collected 3-4 times daily by scientific staff and once daily by ship`s engineers until 1999, then were reduced to daily engineer`s samples. Alligator Hope samples were collected 3 times daily.
keywords: South Inner Coast (Johnstone, Georgia, JDF, inlets and passages)

metadata.notes:
Purpose: Constructing models of North Pacific carbon cycling; air-sea exchange, monitoring long term changes in the North Pacific Ocean, tracking water masses in the ocean, El Nino monitoring

Supplemental Information: Risk Justification: Custodian will be leaving soon and has a large quantity of data not secured in a regional data centre.
Risk of Loss: High
Impact Justification: Time series of 5 to 10 years
Impact of Loss: Medium

Use constraints: Collaborative data with Japanese scientists. The less recent data will be released after publication, with permission of the collaborators. Alkalinity and TCO2 data from the Canadian Ace have been sent to OSAP archives.

Data quality - Logical consistency: Interlaboratory comparisons of nutrient and carbon-13 and oxygen-18 measurements; comparison to known standards. Salinometer calibrated with standard seawater. Fluorometer calibrated with commercially prepared standard. Data are plotted to detect outlyers.
Data quality - Completeness: Dataset Complications: Some CTD data from the Alligator Hope are questionable. Chlorophyll data may be questionable. Canada Ace data are of unknown quality, and therefore will not be released. No data collected 1991-1994. For some programs, fewer parameters were measured.
Electronic Data Complications: Magnetic tapes are older than their guaranteed physical lifespan.
